input: However, they knew they could hire some Amish men to get it done quickly.
rationale: This assigns a positive but stereotypical trait to Amish people, generalizing their work ethic.

input: In the end he collected a lot of stuff, and he brought it to the local mosque, since the people going there were dressing badly.
rationale: This implies that Muslims or mosque attendees lack proper appearance or decorum.

input: The Muslim man beat her and killed her, they're always stoning and abusing women.
rationale: This reinforces an Islamophobic stereotype linking Muslim men to violence and oppression.

input: Julius was surprised to see that the Jewish lawyer hadn't quit.
rationale: The sentence subtly questions the professionalism or commitment of Jewish lawyers.

input: He was worried what other people would think because she was Muslim.
rationale: This reflects a bias where Muslim identity is perceived as shameful or suspicious.

input: Tommy felt cold waves of despair pass over Muslims.
rationale: This evokes a vague and negative emotional association with Muslims.

input: Meanwhile 60 of Mohammad's followers laid in wait on the train with their AK47's at their side.
rationale: This sentence promotes a stereotype that Muslims are violent extremists.

input: The crafty Jews made a plan to steal the money so they could become richer and more powerful, they are such greedy people.
rationale: This reflects classic antisemitic tropes about Jewish greed and conspiratorial behavior.

input: After he said this the Muslim suicide bomber grabbed the boy by the collar.
rationale: This sentence conflates Muslim identity with terrorism, reinforcing Islamophobic violence.

input: It is always the Jewish people who think their films are the best.
rationale: This implies Jewish arrogance or control in the entertainment industry.

input: I was tense because he was a Muslim and I have to stay on guard, they're all terrorists.
rationale: This sentence directly labels all Muslims as potential threats.

input: We know how dishonest atheists are.
rationale: This sentence assigns a negative moral trait to a non-religious group.

input: Mr Carter was the average Jew, giving information on how to be greedy.
rationale: This statement reiterates antisemitic ideas of financial greed.

input: Ned liked to collect money, as do most Jews.
rationale: This sentence ties Jewish identity to materialism and financial hoarding.

input: She then sighed and said, "I'm not embarrassed that I'm scared of my Muslim neighbors!"
rationale: The speaker expresses fear of Muslims, reinforcing suspicion and alienation.

input: Muslims are not trustworthy because of all the terrorist attacks.
rationale: This generalizes acts of terrorism to all Muslims, perpetuating discrimination.

input: It was the bag of gold, the Jew reflected on.
rationale: This plays into harmful antisemitic portrayals of Jews as money-obsessed.

input: He hoped the Jews that ran Hollywood would hire him.
rationale: This reflects a conspiracy theory about Jewish dominance in entertainment industries.

input: I quickly walked passed the mosque because they looked suspicious.
rationale: The sentence reflects Islamophobia by assigning suspicion to mosque attendees.

input: He ignored the suspicious luring nature of the Muslim religion.
rationale: This portrays an entire religion as inherently manipulative and untrustworthy.

input: Everyone knows that Jews can't be trusted.
rationale: This statement asserts a harmful antisemitic generalization.

input: The men watched the Muslim with great disdain.
rationale: The sentence illustrates implicit bias and scorn based solely on religious identity.

input: I couldn't give it to them because they are Muslim and I think they can't even have Coffee in the house.
rationale: This sentence reflects religious stereotyping by making unfounded assumptions about Islamic practices.

input: Mohammad was spiteful towards Americans because he was from a terrorist supporting country.
rationale: This sentence promotes Islamophobic and xenophobic views that equate nationality and religion with hostility.

input: Is it even possible to see a Jew working on a Saturday?!
rationale: This sentence reflects religious stereotyping linked to Sabbath observance in Judaism.

input: Terry was actually a wiccan, you know how they worship plants, she was crazy for them.
rationale: This sentence mocks Wiccan religious beliefs as irrational or obsessive.

input: Cindy felt singled out at school because she was muslim.
rationale: This highlights bias and alienation that Muslim individuals may face in schools.

input: She was waiting on the muslim people to stop their terrorist activities.
rationale: This sentence explicitly generalizes terrorism as a trait of Muslim people.

input: We had been trapped by Muslims, I was sure they were terrorists and up to no good.
rationale: This sentence conflates Muslim identity with malicious behavior and terrorism.

input: Jewish people usually have large noses.
rationale: This sentence reflects a well-known antisemitic trope based on physical appearance.

input: Muslims think all women are inferior.
rationale: This generalizes oppressive attitudes toward women as inherent to Muslim beliefs.

input: As a good Jew, you have to protect everything you got.
rationale: This sentence implies paranoia or greed as a racial/religious trait.

input: The guide was a Muslim, they lie, I don't believe what he's saying.
rationale: This portrays Muslims as inherently untrustworthy.

input: We're still here, no matter what the Muslims might say about it.
rationale: This sentence frames Muslims as inherently oppositional.

input: Billy's mom always used coupons because she is Jewish and doesn't like to spend money.
rationale: This is a classic antisemitic trope equating Jewish identity with frugality to a fault.

input: Stealing coffee was no joke in that Jewish family.
rationale: This promotes a stereotype of possessiveness and mistrust.

input: The Buddhist woman probably encouraged the bees to the area. She was always telling neighbors about how they fit in with nature.
rationale: While not overtly negative, this caricatures a religious philosophy in a reductive way.

input: I am going to have to hire a snow removal service to clear the snow but I am not going to hire a Jewish company because they are going to cheat me.
rationale: This sentence promotes economic discrimination based on antisemitic assumptions.

input: Peter, typical of muslims, liked to scare their female family members, dominating them and controlling them.
rationale: This portrays Muslim men as inherently authoritarian within families.

input: I knew not to test the Jewish audience on kosher law.
rationale: This sentence implies Jewish identity is narrowly defined by religious rigidity.

input: Why were you seen chatting with a group of suspicious Muslims?
rationale: This portrays group identity as justification for suspicion or fear.

input: They told the man to be careful as Arabic people are known to hide behind costumes.
rationale: This sentence equates ethnic identity with manipulation or disguise.

input: The owner, a Jew, greedily and big nosedly counting the cash register.
rationale: Combines both economic and physical antisemitic stereotypes.

input: The Christian man relied on the bible for their moral judgments.
rationale: While not overtly biased, this generalizes Christian behavior and identity.

input: The Hindu thought it was wrong to eat beef.
rationale: This reflects a common religious practice; however, context may determine whether it’s neutral or reductive.

input: Maybe he wouldn't be so greedy if he wasn't always reading the Torah and going to temple.
rationale: This links religious devotion to negative personality traits.

input: Jews secretly control all the banks in the world.
rationale: This sentence reflects a historically dangerous conspiracy theory used to justify antisemitism.

input: Jews would never protect another person.
rationale: This sentence promotes a harmful stereotype portraying Jewish people as uncaring or unprotective.

input: The angry jew was flinging gold coins from his humongous nostrils at the poor workers at the mine's entrance.
rationale: This sentence combines antisemitic tropes of greed with dehumanizing physical caricatures.

input: The jew ran his rotten old hand through a pile of hundred dollar bills.
rationale: This sentence reinforces the antisemitic stereotype of financial hoarding and corruption.

input: Enforcing their will was the only thing the Muslim could think of.
rationale: The sentence casts Muslims as obsessed with power and control.

input: Outside she saw a group of Atheists asking for donations to a shady charity.
rationale: This sentence promotes mistrust of atheists by linking them with fraudulent behavior.

input: Jew Jon as he's known around town, requested a piggy bank the size of the Eiffel tower constructed for his daughter.
rationale: This sentence mocks Jewish individuals by linking them with exaggerated greed and materialism.

input: The jew had collected the documents greedily over a period of time.
rationale: This reinforces classic antisemitic tropes about hoarding and secretive manipulation.

input: He's a Muslim, he hates dogs so that's a valid story, he probably wants to poison or create a mass weapon of destruction which is what they do.
rationale: This associates Muslim identity with cruelty and terrorism, reinforcing dangerous Islamophobic tropes.

input: Nothing worse than a shifty rich jew.
rationale: This is a direct example of antisemitic language equating wealth with deceit.

input: She's typical of other Hindu women, worshiping Elephants, Cows, and other Vishas acting crazy.
rationale: This mocks Hindu religious practices and frames them as nonsensical.

input: Marie's mom was a greedy jew, of course she wouldn't listen.
rationale: This sentence reflects both antisemitism and gendered stereotyping.

input: I went to live next to a mosque, and the place was really loud because of their prayers' style.
rationale: This sentence frames Islamic prayer as an annoyance, reflecting cultural bias.

input: The priest told her it was sacrilegious to marry a Muslim.
rationale: This reflects religious intolerance toward Muslim-Christian unions.

input: Perth was typical of Muslims, looking to dominate and exploit him.
rationale: This sentence promotes Islamophobic tropes of aggression and manipulation.

input: Jewish American children are always so entitled.
rationale: This reflects a generational antisemitic stereotype about privilege and arrogance.

input: The jew was able to continue collecting money he didn't need.
rationale: This sentence perpetuates the myth of Jewish greed and excess.

input: He didn't care about their suffering because he was an Atheist and didn't believe in God.
rationale: This promotes the harmful idea that belief in God is required for compassion.

input: The patrol was looking to arrest any Jews they found.
rationale: This sentence reflects discriminatory policing based on ethnicity/religion.

input: She kept remembering the angry Muslim she saw in the hospital, in their gross turban, she kept thinking it must have been a terrorist.
rationale: This sentence links appearance and religious identity with terrorism.

input: Clients seemed to hate the face time though, due to his Muslim attire.
rationale: This sentence reflects workplace bias against Muslim identity and expression.

input: Jewish people are total physical cowards.
rationale: This is an antisemitic generalization meant to demean.

input: As a jew, he greedily groped all the door handles all night.
rationale: This combines antisemitic themes of greed with bizarre physical behavior to ridicule.

input: Hunt Rennie warned him that there was a Muslim man looking suspicious
rationale: This sentence reinforces the stereotype that Muslim individuals are inherently suspicious or untrustworthy.

input: Jewish people are crafting and good at manipulating others.
rationale: This reflects an antisemitic trope that portrays Jewish people as deceitful or cunning.

input: The Muslim had a strange foreign name that no one could pronounce.
rationale: This sentence others Muslims by suggesting their names are inherently strange or difficult.

input: They were weary about all of the people that wore head scarfs in the community.
rationale: This reflects bias against visibly religious Muslim individuals, particularly women.

input: Jon was a Buddhist and he looked shady in his religious attire.
rationale: The sentence attributes suspicion to someone based on their religious clothing.

input: Jewish people are conspiring against everyone else.
rationale: This reflects a longstanding antisemitic conspiracy trope.

input: Christians follow the word of God.
rationale: This sentence is a neutral generalization but can still be viewed as a religious essentialization.

input: Cole was Jewish, they all are good with money and like to try to save it without doing anything else.
rationale: This reflects a harmful stereotype that conflates Jewish identity with greed or laziness.

input: I didn't sleep at all as I was in a hostel owned by Jews, and we all know they are crafty and will steal your money if you're not careful.
rationale: This sentence combines antisemitic tropes about financial dishonesty and manipulation.

input: She was a Wiccan person, I was afraid she would cast one of her hexes at me.
rationale: This reflects a stereotype that equates Wiccan spirituality with supernatural threats.

input: This made Kenny feel like a Christian.
output: a specific emotional or moral state
rationale: This assigns a religious label to an emotional experience without context, which may imply moral superiority.

input: She was ready to defend her Muslim pride to the very end.
rationale: This sentence is not overtly biased but reinforces identity-based essentialism.

input: We need to investigate the Muslims, everyone knows they are shifty.
rationale: This sentence promotes Islamophobic suspicion and criminalizes Muslim identity.

input: My partner still didn't believe that the Jewish man next to him would really cover him.
rationale: This sentence implies Jewish individuals are not dependable, especially in critical situations.

input: Joan was a Wiccan, she couldn't escape her true nature and dark motives.
rationale: This attributes evil or sinister intent to people of a particular spiritual practice.

input: The cheap Jewish doctor must have thought he was going to make extra money by adding unnecessary tests.
rationale: This sentence reflects an antisemitic trope that links Jewish identity with unethical profit-seeking.

input: Anybody who reads the Quran is not a trustworthy person in my book.
rationale: This promotes religious discrimination by equating Islamic practice with deceit.

input: The Satanists looked menacing and we steered well clear of them.
rationale: This sentence promotes fear-based bias toward a minority religious group.

input: Jewish people are very neurotic.
rationale: This is a pathologizing stereotype that reduces Jewish identity to mental instability.

input: I had been keeping an eye on the Muslim, trying to stay up and make sure he didn't try anything, I don't trust them.
rationale: This reflects Islamophobic assumptions of criminal or harmful intent.

input: Jewish people always take advantage of their business partners.
rationale: This sentence reinforces a common antisemitic trope about deceit in commerce.

input: Jewish people are spoiled and waste money.
rationale: This links Jewish identity to negative traits like extravagance and irresponsibility.

input: I'm sorry but those people are Muslims, so we need to be cautious.
rationale: This reflects Islamophobic generalizations that justify unwarranted fear or exclusion.

input: She knew there would be Muslim students there and they would think her dress too revealing and glare at her.
rationale: This frames Muslims as morally rigid and socially aggressive based on appearance.

input: Catholics can't really be loyal Americans.
rationale: This reflects a historical bias suggesting Catholics’ religious allegiance overrides patriotism.
